lexUnit.name: bellow.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: emit a loud, deep roar, typically in pain or anger.

sentence.text: ` When they heard our bulls bellow the Skroelings ran away ! '
Then listen to the guitar of Ruth Morris , bellowing over in the corner like a love-lorn brontosaurus .
To lie in a tent with stags bellowing round the hills is to touch the marvellous .
Bellowing and rearing on its hind legs , the massive bull lifted him bodily off the ground and shook him repeatedly like a rag-doll .
The thing bellowed and lowered its head again , rain-water-spume-blood-oil running from its jaws .
As Henry turned away and walked down the room Reginald bellowed with laughter ; and when his brother reached the door he shouted , ` Happy Christmas !
Gorbad bellowed in agony and swung Morgor wildly , catching Adolphus a glancing blow across the temple .
With Mario , you felt that if you were walking through the wilds and a bear came bellowing from behind a tree , Mario would seize its paw , shake it vigorously and tell it a good story .
Those closest to her snatched for their swords ; those in the rear shouted encouragement ; the fallen man rolled and clasped his wounded arm , bellowing in outrage .
He started to bellow with mirth .
The engine stopped its fretful clacking and began to bellow with satisfaction as the air became stronger .
Bellowing with pain and leaving a bright trail of blood on the grass , the crazed animal galloped frantically towards its dead calf , over which Joseph and his mother were bending .
He became sadder and sadder ; presently he began to cry and wail , then to scream and bellow with grief .
Something inhuman screeched and bellowed in the storm , and Pearce was swept away from the glass by the shadow , out of sight and into the night -- leaving a bloody smear .
No longer flailing with hideously encrusted , burnt and sinewed arms ; no longer bellowing in fury with the steel trap jaws of some gigantic insect or machine .
He called him a skinny runt and a half-grown whelp , and he bellowed with amusement whenever a threatening movement or a deliberately sudden yell of ` Boo " caused the boy to flinch with alarm .
Cranston , despite his befuddled wits , heard him out then bellowed in righteous indignation .
Then Buddie had slapped his thighs and bellowed with laughter as the biggest bin overturned and its slimy contents rushed towards Frankie in an oozing wave .
As her companions bellowed with laughter , she tossed me aside .
Some way ahead in the bushes a horse bellowed , and Cynan 's angry voice roared defiance .
FOGHORNS bellowed , balloons soared , champagne corks popped … it was “ welcome home ” at last for InterSpray after eight months and 28,000 miles of seagoing endeavour .
